newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss seize 12 million Swiss francs in fake cash.
newsitem.headline: Swiss seize 12 million Swiss francs in fake cash.

text.p: Police seized 12 million Swiss francs ($8.2 million) in forged notes in Switzerland's biggest counterfeiting haul, but prosecutors said on Friday over three million francs might have eluded them.

A Swiss printer, who served a 1970s jail term for counterfeiting, and two Italian men were arrested when the cash was found in a raid on Thursday in the city of Kreuzlingen on the German border at Lake Constance.
"There is evidence that three million (counterfeit Swiss francs) were delivered to Italy and 200,000 to Germany," federal prosecutors said in a statement.
Swiss and German police zeroed in on the suspected counterfeiters after fake 1,000 notes turned up shortly before Christmas in a Swiss bank and a department store, the prosecutors said.

"The reproduction quality of the forgeries is very good and the danger of confusing them with real ones is very high," the statement said. "This is the largest amount of counterfeit Swiss francs ever seized in this country."

It said the notes were produced on an off-set printer. The main signs of forgery were paper that was too thick and the fact that the water sign and a thin metal saftey thread were printed rather than being implanted in the paper.

The Swiss man arrested in the raid was convicted by a Swiss court in 1977 of counterfeiting and sentenced to four years in prison, a prosecution spokesman said. He declined to reveal any details of the two Italian men.
